sentences.sentence: The world is set to speed past an agreed-upon international climate threshold,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: facing rising global temperatures of 2.5 to 2.9 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial times by the end of the century. That's according to a new United Nations report released just days before the start of COP28 in Dubai. The world has already caught a glimpse of what could happen if global warming continues. Since June, the average global temperature each month has been the hottest on record, and now 2023 is set to become the hottest year ever recorded. To keep temperatures to the agreed-upon 1.5 degrees Celsius limit adopted by the 2015 Paris Accord, countries would have to act fast and slash their emissions by 42% by the end of the decade. A challenging task, as emissions from the burning of coal, oil and gas actually rose by 1.2% last year.
